ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my Latin translation skills and learned how to write analytical essays on Caesar. I also learned a ton of Roman history.

I learned how to refine my time management in order to stay on top of our assigned translations and prepare for our weekly quizzes. The content of the course was also deeply interesting, and I learned how to think more critically about the structure of a latin text.

I learned a lot in this class about Caesar as an author, the way he portrayed himself through his works, and the reception of him in his era, subsequent generations, and the modern-day. I also learned a lot about the practice and methodologies of commentaries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength is that the course was mostly discussion based. This allowed us to dive deeper into areas of the text that appealed to us, keeping the course very engaging. A weakness was the volume of translation assigned, which could seem overwhelming at times throughout the semester.

The strength of this class is how we spent a lot of time analyzing the Latin but also reading other secondary literature such as articles on different facets of Caesar, such as his legacy, conquest, epistemicide, and his reception from subsequent generations to today. A weakness is that we were expected to read A LOT of Latin for each class, and I wasn't always able to keep up with the volume of the translation work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely - If you are interested in Latin prose or Caesar, or want to improve your writing skills. It was a great experience through and through and I feel like I got a lot out of it.
Yes. Although I'm not a classics major, I'm very glad I took this course to improve my Latin and learn about how to analyze a text at a deeper level.

I would highly recommend this course! Prof Kraus is an amazing teacher who is really devoted to the scholarship and reception of Caesar, and guided us through his works and the time period incredibly.
